<table width="98%" height="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" summary="layout table">
to the Department of Media, Film and Culture
<td align="left" valign="top" class="bodytext"> <table width="100%" height="121" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

Media, Film and Culture can be studied in a number of undergraduate programmes and combinations. Our experience is that students' careers are enhanced by the depth and breadth of study undertaken rather than the specific subject combinations.

column2: All Saints we have had a relationship with employers in Media, Television, Film, and related Entertainment industries for forty years. We believe the combination of theory and practice is right for our students. Our programmes are designed to produce employable graduates.

column1:
Media analysis requires students to understand the power of the media, the ethical dimensions of the media, and the role of media in a democracy, its impact on our culture and its production of cultural experiences. Our viewing and reading is dominated by our understanding of media, culture and notions of performance, which are developed through television, radio, news presentation, performance, documentary, the Internet and Blogging.

All these topics are interrogated and debated on our programmes. In addition you actually get the chance to make work and to learn the kinds of skills you will need to do on the job.

Culture is therefore embedded in all our programmes. To be able to reflect on the culture we create and to understand the media as part of our developing culture is of vital importance to practitioners and it is also something which employers are very keen on.

All of our staff is committed to their subject. They are practitioners, media-artists, writers, producers, film-makers and academics. It is this combination of skills, which offers a solid academic training with access to practitioners in film, television and other related entertainment industries.
